description:
Gadus chalcogrammus, commonly known as the Alaska pollock or walleye pollock, is a species of marine fish belonging to the cod family, Gadidae. It is a commercially important species found in the cold waters of the North Pacific Ocean.

The Alaska pollock is a medium-sized fish, typically reaching lengths between 30 and 50 centimeters. It has a streamlined, elongated body with a large, terminal mouth and a distinct chin barbel. The coloration of the Alaska pollock is typically olive-green or gray-green on the back, fading to a lighter, silvery-white on the belly.

This species is a pelagic, schooling fish that primarily feeds on small crustaceans, such as krill and copepods, as well as small fish. The Alaska pollock is an important component of the marine ecosystem, serving as a key prey species for a variety of predators, including whales, seals, and seabirds.

Commercially, the Alaska pollock is one of the most heavily harvested fish species in the world, with a global annual catch of over 3 million metric tons. It is a valuable fishery resource, primarily used for the production of surimi (a processed fish product) and other seafood products.

Conservation efforts for the Alaska pollock involve carefully managed catch quotas and regulations to ensure the sustainability of the fishery. Overall, the Alaska pollock is a significant and ecologically important species in the North Pacific Ocean.
